As someone that has worked around and combatted H2S, you see high exposures usually when dealing with CHT/black water ruptures (bodily waste sewage) and other decaying organic material like sea water (and the decaying is sped up when mixed for AFFF firefighting purposes). H2S is also known as The Sailor Killer because of the threat it can pose on board. The reason H2S isn't building up in your AFFF extinguisher at your workplace is because it's mixed using freshwater which decays and rusts metal much, much slower.

I Work in a crude oil refinery and in my unit there are pipes with oil fumes containing up to 100000 ppm hydrogen-sulfide. Even a small leak in this pipes could poison the air around the unit up to 100m. I had a leak during a nightshift, I couldn't smell anything, but my H2S warner peaked out at 200ppm. I quickly put on my escape mask and rushed out of the unit. I went to the company doctor the same night because my eyes burned, had headache, dizziness and nausea. I got some medicine and I felt better quickly.

Nobody knows the actual H2S concentration I was exposed to, that night. But I was pretty lucky. At 1000 ppm you can die within seconds of inhalation. H2S along with CO are pretty dangerous gases do deal with.

Hydrogen sulfide is a gaseous acid. When you breathe it in it pulls hydrogen molecules from your nasal passages. That is part of what you are smelling. PH stands for potential of hydrogen or power of hydrogen. When your pH is low it is an acid. Meaning it's looking for hydrogen molecules to even itself out, because everything in this world wants to level out. Acid touches your skin it pulls the hydrogen molecules out of your tissues. Strong acids pulling the hydrogen makes the skin look as if it is melting.

Fun fact about hydrogen sulfide: humans are so incredibly sensitive to the stuff that we can smell it in concentrations as low as 0.5 parts per billion.

Less fun fact: the stuff is pretty toxic (similar to carbon monoxide in toxicity). If you ever notice the smell disappearing, stop what you are doing and get away from the source immediately. Don't think "ah, seems like it's gone", it's not. If you don't get away, chaces are you'll pass out and fall to the floor. Since hydrogen sulfide is heavier than air, this will lead to you inhaling more and more of the stuff and most likely dying as a result.

I work in the oilfield for a company who's primary job is providing H2s safety/mitigation. It occurs naturally with decaying organic material (which is why it's in your poop/farts/etc), but interestingly only some oil wells have it. Some have none at all, while some are extremely high, with very little rhyme or reason.

It takes ~1,000ppm to kill you in a single breath, and we regularly work on Wells with >200,000-400,000ppm (20-40%). Thats 200-400 times more than it takes to kill in a single breath.

Perhaps most interestingly, when H2s contacts iron, it almost instantly corrodes it, and makes a special type of rust called Iron Sulfide. Iron sulfide is special because it violently oxidizes when it comes into contact with even just atmospheric levels of oxygen. So if you open a tank, for example, that contains iron sulfide scale, and the scale isn't wet, it will spontaneously combust.
